quoteFirst: The ship was now ‘abandoned,’ and panic parties were sent away in the one remaining boat and two rafts. The enemy, still submerged, proceeded to circle the ship, inspect her closely, approach the boat and rafts, and then at
quoteLast: rose to the surface on the port bow 250 yards off and began shelling _Penshurst_ with her after gun. The Q-ship was about to open fire, but, owing to having settled down so much by the stern, the gun there could not be sufficiently depressed to bear.
title: Q-Ships and Their Story
author: Chatterton, E. Keble (Edward Keble), 1878-1944

quoteLast: Tanner reported to Lukin that he had won the whole wood with the exception of strong points in the north-west abutting on Longueval and the northern orchards. He had succeeded brilliantly in the first part of his task, but the problem of Delville was far less to carry the wood than to hold it.
title: The history of the South African forces in France
author: Buchan, John, 1875-1940

title: The Royal Mail: Its Curiosities and Romance

quoteFirst: The next naval victory was won by Captain William Bainbridge, this time in command of the Constitution, forty-four guns, over the British thirty-eight-gun frigate Java, Captain Henry Lambert. The battle began at
quoteLast: , and at 4.05 p. m., the British frigate was "an unmanageable wreck." The Java at length surrendered, having lost sixty killed, besides one hundred and one wounded, while the loss of the Constitution was nine killed and twenty-five wounded.
title:
The Land We Live In
The Story of Our Country
author: Mann, Henry, 1848-1915

quoteLast: . If you don't get there by that time it will be of no use, but if you're on time you'll beat the town--and the country too.”
title: Gallegher and Other Stories
